One approach would be to treat the process as a 'job' that might take
time =
to complete. In this case, you could use something like the
following:

POS=
T /job-queue/
<migrate-document>
  <source-id />
  <destination-id />
</mig=
rate-document>

RESPONSE 202 Accepted
Location: /job-queue/{job-id}

GET /j=
ob-queue/{job-id}
would return a document showing the status of the job.
On=
ce the job is complete, the resource could include a <link
rel=3D"delete" h=
ref=3D"source-id" /> to instruct the client to complete
the workflow.

The =
server could to whatever is deemed appropriate to guard against
broken work=
flow including locking {source-id} and/or {destination-id}
while the job is=
 in progress, reporting 405 (Method Not Allowed) for
DELETE /{source-id} wh=
ile the job is in process, etc.
